abstract.para: &App; provides a way for blind individuals to access scanned sheet music in a convenient format (&bmn;).
This book serves as an introduction to &bmn; for those readers that are not familiar with it yet. It is also the User's Manual for &App;.

partintro.para: &Bmn; is an internationally accepted standard for expressing musical ideas in tactile readable form.

Since &App; is mostly useless to a user who does not know &bmn;, the first part of this book is dedicated to teaching the very basics of &bmn;. If you are already familiar with the international &bmn; standard, you can safely skip over this section.

sect1.title: Notes and rests
sect1.para: In &bmn; pitch and duration of a musical event are encoded into a single character.

However, since 6-dot braille has a fairly limited amount of available patterns (64) an ambiguity had to be introduced to allow for values smaller than eighth notes. The same patterns are reused again, from sixteenth notes to 128th notes. I.e., the dot pattern for a whole note can either mean a whole or a sixteenth note. In most cases it is immediately clear by knowing the time signature which of the possibilities is right. In those rare cases where it is not clear to the reader, special symbols are used to indicate which of the two possibilities is refered to.

partintro.para: &App; is not a full &omr; solution. To be able to read sheet music, you will first need to obtain the music you want to read with &App; in MusicXML format.
The following chapters are concerned with how and where you can obtain sheet music in MusicXML.

chapter.title: What is MusicXML?
chapter.para: MusicXML is a &XML; based file format for storing musical notation. It is being developed by Recordare LLC.

chapter.title: How to create MusicXML scores?
chapter.para: MusicXML is now supported by almost all commercial applications dealing with musical scores in one way or another. There are basically two ways to obtain a score in MusicXML format. Either you already have it in some computerized form, then you need to investigate how to convert your data to MusicXML. Many commercial notation editors offer a way to export to MusicXML these days. If you have the music on paper, you need some &omr; software to scan and recognize your music.
A list of applications that allow to save or export to MusicXML format can be found here.

chapter.title: MusicXML on the Internet
chapter.para: Since MusicXML is increasingly being used as an interchange format between different music notation software, it is increasingly being used as the canonical format to distribute musical notation over the Internet.
Therefore, there is a chance that the music you are looking for is already available on the Internet in MusicXML format.
Below is a list of some Internet resources that offer MusicXML files for download.

partintro.para: Now that we have acquainted ourselves with &bmn; and know how to obtain MusicXML documents we can go on and examine in detail how &App; can be used to automatically transcribe scanned sheet music to &bmn;.

chapter.title: Overview
chapter.para: The user interface of &App; closely resembles a typical editor application. At the top is a menu bar for convenient access to the most used actions. The main part of the application is a text edit window which contains the result of transcribing the currently opened MusicXML file to &bmn;.

You can use the caret to navigate inside the resulting braille music document as in other editing applications. The caret position is context sensitive. For instance, if you move the caret the status area will automatically be updated with textual information about the braille symbol currently underneath the caret.

&App; also offers the possibility to play back the score currently opened. During playback, the caret position will update synchronous to the music. Additionally, there is the possibility to play individual parts of a score, or just a single note.

question.para: Why can't I read the default output of &App; on LinuxLinux with BRLTTYBRLTTY?

answer.para: &App; uses Unicode by default to output braille and text such that sighted and blind users can read the output without major confusion.
However, the Unicode braille row is only supported by the braille display driver BRLTTY on Linux since release 3.10. You will also need the braille fonts provided on .
